description: Attested from around 1400 as Middle English canon, canoun, from Old French canon, from Italian cannone, from Latin canna, from Ancient Greek Œ∫Œ¨ŒΩŒΩŒ± (k√°nna, ‚Äúreed‚Äù), from Akkadian íÑÄ (qan√ª, ‚Äúreed‚Äù), from Sumerian íÑÄíàæ (gi.na). Doublet of canyon.
This spelling was not fixed until about 1800.

nouns.description: cannon (countable and uncountable, plural cannons or (mainly UK) cannon)

entries.meaning: A complete assembly, consisting of an artillery tube and a breech mechanism, firing mechanism or base cap, which is a component of a gun, howitzer or mortar. It may include muzzle appendages.

definitionGroups.group: Any similar device for shooting material out of a tube.

entries.meaning: A bone of a horse's leg, between the fetlock joint and the knee or hock.

examples: In English billiards, a cannon is when one's cue ball strikes the other player's cue ball and the red ball on the same shot; and it is worth two points.

entries.meaning: (baseball, figuratively, informal) The arm of a player who can throw well.
examples: He's got a cannon out in right.

entries.meaning: (engineering) A hollow cylindrical piece carried by a revolving shaft, on which it may, however, revolve independently.

(historical) A cylindrical item of plate armor protecting the arm, particularly one of a pair of such cylinders worn with a couter, the upper cannon protecting the upper arm and the lower cannon protecting the forearm.
(printing, uncountable) Alternative form of canon (‚Äúa large size of type‚Äù)
(xiangqi) A piece which moves horizontally and vertically like a rook but captures another piece by jumping over a different piece in the line of attack.

examples: I also learned never to conspicuoulsy[sic] watch a cannon while he was working. Pickpockets dislike being watched, even by those who may be "right," because they become uneasy and clumsy and feel conspicuous.

verbs.description: cannon (third-person singular simple present cannons, present participle cannoning, simple past and past participle cannoned)

entries.meaning: (sports, billiards, snooker, pool) To play the carom billiard shot; to strike two balls with the cue ball.
examples: The white cannoned off the red onto the pink.

entries.meaning: To fire something, especially spherical, rapidly.
To collide or strike violently, especially so as to glance off or rebound.
examples: [‚Ä¶]  he heard the right-hand goal post crack as a pony cannoned into it‚Äîcrack, splinter, and fall like a mast.
